Not wanting to arouse suspici Jimmy STANDS and trudges into ANOTHER CAR... ..-and there, sitting alone at the opposite end, is MIKE. Thousand-yard stare in his eyes, trying to comprehend how life fell apart in a matter of a few hours... Jimmy walks that way and SITS across from him.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Looks like we're stuck together tonight. Mike looks at him, eyes burning with resentment. A moment passes, then:

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: I killed that cop, didn’t I?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Hard to tell with those things. Coulda missed the vitals, an officer in good health, EMTs quick to the scene.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: What are the chances of that?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Zilch. You blew up his gut. Family’s makin’ funeral arrangements. (off Mike's glare) I’m the expert at this thing, right? A beat.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Where are the girls?

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: At my brother-in-law’s.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Get over there as soon as we’re let off. Borrow a car, buy a plane ticket — do whatever you gotta do — just get outta the city.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: (chuckles, a bit delirious at this point) Get outta the city?  51.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: That’s right.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: And go where? My beach house in the Caribbean?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: If ya got one, sure.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: (snapping, reality setting in) Where the hell am I gonna go?! Huh!? This is where I live! This is where my family lives! I don’t got nowhere else to go! A few RIDERS take notice and stare at Mike.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: (to an ELDERLY GAWKER) T’fuck are you lookin’ at? Turn around. (Gawker turns away, then) Look, Michael, I know how these things work... EXT. THE ABBEY PUB — NIGHT As the lights come up inside.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Right now Shawn’s got everyone meeting up at The Abbey. INT. THE ABBEY PUB — NIGHT Shawn and Pat stand before TWO DOZEN brawny GANG MEMBERS, dressed for the cold, eagerly awaiting marching orders.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: From there they’re gonna start knockin’ on doors. EXT. DUPLEX IN FISHTOWN (SARAH’S BROTHER’S HOUSE) — NIGHT Someone’s POUNDING on the door. Sarah’s brother, DREW, 27 opens it revealing TWO OF SHAWN’S MEN (1 & 2). They PUSH ASIDE and make their way into the home, searching under tables, in closets, et al. Drew’s WIFE and TWO KIDS cower the family room couch.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Family, friends, co-workers...  52. INT. BASEMENT — NIGHT LIGHTS COME ON over the unfinished space. GANG MEMBER 1 m his way down the stairs, looks around for signs of life a finally heads back up. REVEAL: SARAH, CATELYN and LILY hiding in the space under stairwell. Shaking, afraid to breathe...

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ...anyone that can connect them to you. INT. 2ND PRECINCT — MUSTER ROOM — NIGHT Packed with POLICE OFFICERS. CLOSE-UPS OF FACES: Some sob others boiling with impotent rage.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And the cops, they got their own motivation. CAPTAIN DALEY, blood on fire, enters and pins photos of Whalen and Edney on the corkboard for everyone to see.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Right now that fat fuck Daley’s tellin’ em about some kid who lost his father... some wife without a husband... EXT. 2ND PRECINCT — LOT — NIGHT As DOZENS OF CROWN VICS leave the parking lot...

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Yunno what they do to cop killers? They don’t like to leave it ina jury’s hands. EXT. PHILADELPHIA — VARIOUS ANGLES (POLICE & SHAWN’S CREW The BLACK-AND-WHITES SPREAD OUT... SHAWN’S CREW PROWLS th streets... FLASHLIGHTS sweep across dark alleys... STREET COPS comb TRAIN STATIONS, BUS STOPS, PUBLIC RESTROOMS... SHAWN’S THUGS RANSACK JIMMY'S HOME, DESTROYING EVERYTHING We get the feeling that every inch of the city is being watched.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Every cop and hood in this city is hunting us down...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INT. SUBWAY CAR — ON JIMMY

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Forget about this place. Get your wife, get the girls, and make a life somewhere else. A long moment as Mike considers Jimmy's advice. Finally:

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: .--No what?

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: I’m not running.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: You don’t got a choice.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: I didn’t do anything wrong.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: You think that matters?

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Someone else was there... Someone else saw what happened at Colin’s house.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: ...Who?

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Curtis... but everyone calls him Legs. INT. THE ABBEY PUB — STORAGE ROOM — NIGHT KENAN sits in a folding chair. He’s a mess. Sobbing, scar leg bandaged from when Mike stabbed him. TWO GANG MEMBERS stand nearby. He looks up as Shawn and Pat enter.

dialogues.speaker: KENAN
dialogues.text: (blubbering) I’m so sorry, Mr. Maguire — I’m so fuckin’ sorry. Shawn calmly KNEELS DOWN in front of him.

dialogues.speaker: SHAWN
dialogues.text: It’s okay. Look at me. (Kenan meets Shawn’s eyes) Did he suffer?

dialogues.speaker: BRENDAN
dialogues.text: Colin...?

dialogues.speaker: SHAWN
dialogues.text: Did my son suffer?  54.

dialogues.speaker: KENAN
dialogues.text: (shakes his head) Uh-uh... No, no, he just kinna... went down... it all happened real quick... Relieved by this, Shawn PATS Kenan’s cheek.

dialogues.speaker: SHAWN
dialogues.text: Thank you. TIGHT ON: SHAWN’S HAND. A HUNTING KNIFE falls from his sl into the palm of his hand.

dialogues.speaker: KENAN
dialogues.text: I’m really sorry, Mr. Maguire. He, he was my best friend and — Before he can finish, Shawn STABS HIM IN THE GUT with the knife. Then QUICKLY, FURIOUSLY JABS IT IN AND OUT a dozen times. All his rage surging forth at once.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kenan’s eyes widen in shock and horror. His face contorts horrible anguish. With his palm, Shawn SINKS the knife in deeper... Kenan’s head slumps limply... dead... INT. BATHROOM — MINUTES LATER BLOOD SWIRLS DOWN A SINK DRAIN. As Shawn RINSES the knife in the sink, he catches a glimp of his reflection in the mirror. Can’t help but notice ho old he looks. Maybe too old for this anymore.

dialogues.speaker: PAT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I just got off the phone with Rourke. In the mirror, we see Pat standing in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: SHAWN
dialogues.text: And...?

dialogues.speaker: PAT
dialogues.text: He’s available. A beat. Shawn seems to be making a decision. Finally —

dialogues.speaker: SHAWN
dialogues.text: Make the call. EXT. SUBURBAN STREET — BRYN MAWR — ESTABLISHING A pretty Colonial home on a quiet, leafy street. MUSIC UP: Beethoven’s ‘Allegretto in C Minor’ —  55. INT. STUDY — NIGHT — CLOSE ON A DIORAMA. The Battle of Antietam. MINIATURE FIGURINES, U and CONFEDERATE SOLDIERS, in the throes of the epic strug CANONS, FLAGS, HORSES. BLOOD, PAIN, ANGUISH. TIGHT ON A MILITARY FIGURINE — a UNION SOLDIER seen under MAGNIFYING GLASS. A tiny paintbrush ever-so-carefully gra his bayonet blade with a streak of silver acrylic. REVERSE — a haunting, pale mineral-blue eye staring down us. Focused, unblinking. WIDER REVEALS — ANDREW PRICE 40s, a tall, fit man sitting at the desk. Bespectacled, bookish, hair neatly parted. He’s wearing a plaid button- shirt and pressed Dockers as he examines the figurine, ke to analyze every angle and line. The PHONE RINGS. Price doesn't break focus. He carefully sets his paintbru down, shuts off the classical music on the Bose Wave ster and answers.

dialogues.speaker: PRICE
dialogues.text: Price residence, Andrew speaking... Mmm hmm... Mmm hmm... He reaches for a memo pad, pushes his glasses back agains the bridge of his nose. Writes now with perfect penmanshi 2 @ $100,000 each

dialogues.speaker: PRICE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And the names, please. Mmm hmm... Michael Conlow

dialogues.speaker: PRICE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Jimmy did you say? Mmm hmm... Jimmy Conlow

dialogues.speaker: PRICE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And where are they now?... Mmm hmn... INT. WALK-IN CLOSET/BEDROOM — NIGHT As Price enters and reaches for an ALUMINUM BRIEFCASE on top shelf. Takes it down and sets it on the bed. OPENS th lid revealing two FN FIVE-SEVEN PISTOLS with laser sights He slips on a SHOULDER HOLSTER and slides the two pistols into place. Reaches for his LL Bean field coat now.  56. INT. FAMILY ROOM — NIGHT It’s like a Rockwell painting come to life. Garland, tins a cozy fire. Neatly-wrapped gifts surround a tastefully adorned Douglas Fir. Price’s WIFE, 40, watches a sitcom i her comfy sweats and reindeer socks. TWO YOUNG BOYS play an elaborate CHRISTMAS TRAIN SET on the floor. Price descends the stairs and enters the room.

dialogues.speaker: WIFE
dialogues.text: Who was that on the phone, hon?

dialogues.speaker: PRICE
dialogues.text: Just the office. One of the servers crashed.

dialogues.speaker: WIFE
dialogues.text: But, sweetie, it’s eleven o’clock.

dialogues.speaker: PRICE
dialogues.text: It shouldn’t take very long. Do you need anything while I’m out?

dialogues.speaker: WIFE
dialogues.text: Will you get some skim milk and eggs for the morning?

dialogues.speaker: PRICE
dialogues.text: Mmm hmm. (smiles to the boys) Be good for your mother. They're too engrossed in the train set to respond.

dialogues.speaker: WIFE
dialogues.text: Love you, honey.

dialogues.speaker: PRICE
dialogues.text: Love you, too. Price goes. INT. GARAGE/INT. AUDI A7 — NIGHT Price climbs into the Audi, starts the engine. Arranges a POLICE SCANNER on the dashboard. Chatter between a DISPAT and STREET UNITS. He reverses out of the drive and tears the street. INT. ROW HOME — MAYFAIR — NIGHT DOG FOOD IS POURED INTO A BOWL. Standing in the outmoded kitchen, EDDIE CONLON, 55, tall, hardy, broad, tilts the bag of Iams over the bowl. A smal plays on the counter. An old, sickly Labrador nears, snif at the food a moment.  57.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Go ‘head. Eat. Come on, you like this shit. The Lab moseys off, disinterested.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh for Christ’s sake. There’s a KNOCK at the door. Eddie trudges that way, hobb on two ruined roofer’s knees. More KNOCKING. LOUDER now.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Yeah yeah, I’m comin’! (arrives at the door) Who is it?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: It’s me, Eddie, open up.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Who’s me?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: It’s your brother. It’s Jimmy.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: (pauses, suspiciously now) What do you want?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: Just open the goddamn door, will ya! Reluctantly, Eddie opens the door. SEES Jimmy...and then standing there beside him.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: (nonplussed) Michael? What — what’re you doin’ here? What’s going on?

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: How ya doin’, Uncle Ed?

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Good, yeah... (NOTICES the blood on Jimmy's sweatshirt) Is that blood? Jimmy —

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: We got jumped.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Jumped? Jesus Christ... (yanking them inside) Get in, get in. Jimmy and Mike step inside. Eddie closes the door, locks  58.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to Jimmy) Go in the bathroom. Hurry up. Jimmy moves off. WE FOLLOW EDDIE, older-brother-mode now as he moves into KITCHEN... gathers a batch of hand towels... opens a cabi and takes down peroxide, bandages, et al... As he does th SOUND of the TV becomes prominent:

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER ON TV, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: — That’s right, Ken. Police are on the hunt tonight for two suspects identified as James Conlon and his son, Michael Conlon... Eddie WHIRLS to the TV. Did he hear that right? PICTURES JIMMY AND MIKE appear on the screen now. REPORTER ON TV (CONT’D) .+-who they say took the lives of two veteran police officers during a deadly chase and shooting on the Vine Street Expressway. FOOTAGE of the accident scene now. The hideous wreck. Whi sheets covering bodies.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: (sotto) Jesus Christ... Feeling a presence, Eddie turns back to find Mike standin the doorway. He’s been watching. His head falls, unable t proffer an excuse. A look of resignation registers on Eddie’s face...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jimmy takes his sweatshirt off. His flabby skin plagued w tattoos: boyhood braveries that now look faded, cartoonis He turns the shower on, leans in and washes the flesh wou Eddie enters with the towels, bandages and a change of clothes for Jimmy which he sets on the counter.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Thanks. Two fuckin’ spics right there on Cottman Ave... Knife this long... Got my wallet, too. Whole fuckin’ neighborhood’s goin’ to shit...

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: (solemnly) What’ve you gotten yourself into this time, Jimmy? (off look) It’s all over the news in there...  59. Resigned, Jimmy shuts off the water and sits on the toile He begins to wrap his arm with the bandages.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: I need the keys to your cabin.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: What for?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: (re: Mike) Get his wife and girls up there while we figure this out. I’m gonna need a car too. And cigarettes if ya got any.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: It wasn’t enough that you ruined your own life, now you’re bringing Michael into this?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: I’m not bringin’ him into anything. I’m tryin’ to get him out.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Two cops, Jimmy? Shawn put you up to this? He ask you to handle something for him? (no answer) The worst thing that ever happened to you was meetin’ that sonofabitch. (still no answer) Goddamnit I’m talking to you!

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: (STANDS UP)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AND I’m LISTENING! WHADDAYOU WANT FROM

dialogues.speaker: ME, EDDIE
dialogues.text: Their faces are just inches apart. Years, decades really, hurt, betrayal, and disappointment rising to the surface.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: in the den, listening.

dialogues.speaker: BATHROOM
dialogues.text: A tense face-off between the brothers finally dissolves. Jimmy sits back down and continues wrapping his arm.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: (sotto) T’fuck did I even come here for?

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Shawn’s not gonna be able to get you outta this one.  60.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Yeah, well, you’1ll get your wish then. What were the words you used that time on the stand? The animal belongs in a cage, Judge. (a dark chuckle) Helluva’n endorsement, big brother. Eddie feels a pang of guilt.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Gimme the keys to your cabin and your car. I swear ta Christ it’1l be the last time you ever hafta see my face. Off Eddie, a deal he can’t refuse... EXT. EDDIE’S DUPLEX — DRIVEWAY — NIGHT Jimmy and Mike sit inside Eddie’s salt-encrusted OLDSMOBI ACHIEVA. Jimmy, now dressed in his brother’s sweatshirt a flannel coat, starts the engine. Eddie leans in the windo and hands Jimmy a pack of Malboro Reds.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Thanks. Jimmy lights one.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: There are two rifles in the closet downstairs.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Okay...

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Listen. Mom’s in the hospital... (off Jimmy’s look) She slipped on some ice comin’ outta Church this mornin’. Fractured her pelvis, bruised her legs up pretty bad. They got her overnight at Jefferson. I just thought, before all this... if you wanted to see her... Jimmy NODS. Eddie looks at his little brother, then at Mi unsure what else to say at this point.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: God bless. Jimmy reverses out of the drive. Eddie watches the car va down the street and stays watching long after it’s gone. EXT. CROWN LIMOUSINE — FISHTOWN — NIGHT — ESTABLISHING A small, fenced-in lot houses a fleet of limousines.  61. MAN’S VOICE (V.O.) Reservation was made under the name Stevan Kujovic... INT. CROWN LIMO, MANAGER'S OFFICE — NIGHT Harding and Flores sit across from VINCE FARINA, 60s, a c smoking workaholic with thinning hair slicked back over h scalp. His desk is choked with invoices, receipts, antaci

dialogues.speaker: FARINA
dialogues.text: Pick-up was 7:00 at Rittenouse Plaza. Two passengers going to the airport.

dialogues.speaker: HARDING
dialogues.text: They make it there?

dialogues.speaker: FARINA
dialogues.text: Beats me. But the client never called. Which makes me believe Mike picked ‘em up.

dialogues.speaker: HARDING
dialogues.text: (to Flores) Run a check with the airlines. (back to Farina now) How long’s Conlon worked for you?

dialogues.speaker: FARINA
dialogues.text: Almost two years now.

dialogues.speaker: FLORES
dialogues.text: Good worker?

dialogues.speaker: FARINA
dialogues.text: Best employee I got. Never missed a pick-up. Never got a complaint. Every driver was like him I wouldn't have stomach ulcers the size’a silver dollars. Instead I got fifteen shitheads and one saint. He tosses back two horse pills and washes them down with glass of Alka-Seltzer. Harding’s CELL PHONE VIBRATES. He stands, ducks out into HALLWAY and answers:

dialogues.speaker: HARDING
dialogues.text: Harding.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: It’s Jimmy Conlon.

dialogues.speaker: HARDING
dialogues.text: Very funny, Tornetta, but I don’t got time for this shit right now.  62. INT. OLDSMOBILE ACHIEVA — NIGHT Jimmy’s on his cell phone, looking down at Harding's card

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: It’s Saturday. Isn’t that greasehead losin’ his ass at the craps table?

dialogues.speaker: BETWEEN JIMMY AND HARDING
dialogues.text: A beat. Harding, realizing it really is Jimmy. Then:

dialogues.speaker: HARDING
dialogues.text: I hope you’re on a plane to the Shangri-La, Conlon.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: I tried. Flight was booked.

dialogues.speaker: HARDING
dialogues.text: Then breathe in that fresh air cause where you’re going you’1l be lucky if you get fifteen minutes of that a week. Rest’a the time you'll be rottin’ away inside a four-by-six concrete box.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: What was the number you had me at?

dialogues.speaker: HARDING
dialogues.text: Sixteen.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Wrong again.

dialogues.speaker: HARDING
dialogues.text: No shit. Only this time I got thirty witnesses who saw you run a cop car off the expressway, killing one officer while your son finished off his partner.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: What if I told you my son didn’t have anything to do with this?

dialogues.speaker: HARDING
dialogues.text: I'd tell ya I don’t give a shit. I’m gonna put him away just for being related to you. Silence on both ends. Each waiting for the other to flinc Finally: HARDING (CONT’D) It’s gotta be a weird feeling for you, Conlon.  63.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: What does?

dialogues.speaker: HARDING
dialogues.text: Tables turned. Being the one hunted. Even your pal Shawn Maguire wants you dead. You don’t have a friend left in this world. A beat to let that sink in. Jimmy doesn’t object. Can’t. HARDING (CONT’D) Turn yourself in. Make this easy. Jimmy considers it for a moment, then:

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: You drink coffee, Harding?

dialogues.speaker: HARDING
dialogues.text: Six cups a day for the last thirty years. Helps me shit regularly.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Put in a little extra sugar. It’s gonna be a long night. Jimmy hangs up. INT. OFFICE HALLWAY — SAME Harding hears the DIAL TONE, tucks the phone away. He gla back into the office where Farina is talking to Flores:

dialogues.speaker: FARINA
dialogues.text: — You ask me, none of it makes any sense. I never even knew Mike had a father. He told me his old man died when he was five years old... Off Harding, replaying Jimmy’s words in his head... INT. OLDSMOBILE ACHIEVA — NIGHT Jimmy watches as the front door of Drew’s home opens. Mik exits with Lily in his arms; Sarah holds Catelyn. Jimmy looks at the faces of his granddaughters peeking through bulky winter coats and knit caps. It's the first time he’s ever seen them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He smiles faintly. EXT. STREET — CONTINUOUS As Jimmy steps out of the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is Santa coming tonight?

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Not tonight, sweetheart.

dialogues.speaker: CATELYN
dialogues.text: Soon?

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Only a few more days. 64. Sarah notices Jimmy first. He waves awkwardly. She ignore him. Now Catelyn sees him and hugs Mike tight, trained to wary of strangers.

dialogues.speaker: CATELYN
dialogues.text: Who’s that man, daddy? Jimmy's about to respond, step forward to meet her. Then:

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Nobody, honey. Let’s get in the car now, okay. A little piece of Jimmy dies right then. He stalls, stand there, empty, as the girls are loaded into an SUV. INT. OLDSMOBILE ACHIEVA, MOVING — NIGHT Jimmy drives, smokes. Mike’s in the passenger seat, stari pensively out his window. SEES a GROUP of CHRISTMAS CAROL parents and young children, going house to house. Makes h think of his daughters... his wife... his life before thi

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Is it a boy or a girl?

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: (snaps from his melancholy) Uhh... boy.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: How far along is she?

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Almost eight months.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: You got a name picked out?

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Yeah... Jimmy waits for the next sentence. But Mike’s not sharing

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Still workin’ that security job?  65.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: (shakes his head ‘no’) Cutbacks. Got ridda half the staff. Drivin’ a limo now.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Make a decent livin’ doin’ that?

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: What’s a decent livin’? I make enough to pay the mortgage, feed my girls and take my wife to dinner once a month. (meaning Jimmy) There are worse ways to make a buck, I guess.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: But you like it? I mean, you’re happy?

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: (chuckles) Since when do you give a shit if I’m happy? This is for your own sake, right? Peace of mind? I say I’m happy, that life turned out alright, and you don’t feel so shitty for walking out on mom and me?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: That’s right. So are you?

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Happy?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: I'd be happier if I was playing third base for the Phillies, but something tells me that aint gonna happen.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: You don’t got the arm for third anyway. (off Mike's look) I’m just sayin’. Second maybe. Third? No shot. Ball’s’d be skipppin’ into first.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: (shakes his head) You really are a piece of work, you know that?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: I’m not tryin’ to bust balls, it’s just an honest assessment.  66.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Here’s what I think about your honest assessment. (raises his middle finger)

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: I use’ta watch your games.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Bullshit.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: In high school. I’d sit in the outfield, though. Couldn’t stand bein’ around the other parents. Every asshole tellin’ you how his kid’s the next Lou Gehrig. A beat. What Jimmy says next doesn’t come easily:

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You were a good player, though. Good, solid ball player. Fast. Tough. Smart. You didn’t tear your knee up, maybe things coulda turned out different. Mike looks over at him. Had no idea he knew about that.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Get a tryout, make a minor league club. Who knows? But that’s life, yunno? It don’t offer any do-overs.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Believe me I know. A few silent moments pass. Only the sound of 1060 NEWSRAD The ANCHOR tells of plummeting temperatures. It’s suggest the elderly stay inside.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: She would still ask for you, yunno? That used to drive me crazy. I'd be in the hospital room with her and all of a sudden she’d say, Oh Michael, I just wish your father was here... And later, when she got really sick, she’d wake up in the middle of the night calling your name.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Your mother and I were together a long time. They weren't all bad years.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Didn't you ever think about comin’ by? I mean, just to... say hello, see how she was doin’... watch a stupid goddamn tv show for all I care. That never crossed your mind?  67.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: I watched my father go that way. Took him five years to die. By the end he weighed a hundred and ten pounds. (shakes his head) Promised myself I’d never go through that again.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Well good for you. You kept your promise. And she died alone.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: You thought she deserved someone better. I guess I can understand that.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: No, that’s not it. I just wanted her to hate you the way I hated you. INT. HOMIDCIDE UNIT — 750 RACE — NIGHT TIGHT ON: an article in the Philadelphia Inquirer from 19 PICK UP WORDS: In a stunning verdict, Jimmy ‘The Gravedig Conlon was acquitted of the murders... cu (PHOTO in article): JIMMY, 30s here, in a courtroom, hugging Shawn following the not guilty verdict. cU (b.g. of same PHOTO): HARDING, early 30s, in the rear the courtroom, standing beside his ex-partner, TORNETTA, apoplectic with rage.

dialogues.speaker: ON HARDING
dialogues.text: At his desk, scanning the article behind reading glasses. Feeling weirdly nostalgic. The night dredging up memories

dialogues.speaker: FLORES, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: Son’s cleaner than Mr. Rogers. Pulled from his reverie, Harding tucks the article into a drawer. Spins his chair to Flores at the neighboring desk

dialogues.speaker: HARDING
dialogues.text: No priors?

dialogues.speaker: FLORES
dialogues.text: Not even a parking ticket. I talked to one’a his co-workers. Said he enrolled in business courses up at Temple. Wanted to get outta the late-night-no- holiday hacking life. Harding slips off his glasses, reclines, thinking.  68.

dialogues.speaker: HARDING
dialogues.text: Young father trying to make a better life for his family suddenly goes on a cop-killing rampage with an old man he’s tellin’ everyone is dead. (shakes his head: it doesn’t compute) Who called it in?

dialogues.speaker: FLORES
dialogues.text: (reading the dispatch log) Michael. Told dispatch his father shot and killed a man in the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: HARDING
dialogues.text: So why does he run when the cops get there? (Flores shrugs: beats me) Lemme see the log... Flores hands it to Harding. Harding reads... confused, th troubled by what he doesn’t see. He abruptly grabs his overcoat off his chair — HARDING (CONT’D) Come on. Flores LEAPS UP, wiggles into his coat, then hurries to c up to Harding who’s already out the door. INT. CITY HOSPITAL MORGUE — HALLWAY — NIGHT Shawn and Pat are escorted down a long, sterile hallway b ATTENDANT. They arrive at a door. Pat waits outside as Sh enters the room... -+.COLIN’S BODY lies on a metal table. Shawn approaches a stands over him, absorbing the finality of this moment.

dialogues.speaker: SHAWN
dialogues.text: That’s Colin... That’s my son. Shawn slips his hand out of his overcoat pocket and gentl runs his fingers over his son’s face... as if to memorize features. INT. HOSPITAL CAFETERIA — NIGHT Shawn and Pat sip cups of coffee as they wait to sign pap Shawn is quiet, contemplative.

dialogues.speaker: PAT
dialogues.text: Want some more coffee? Shawn shakes his head ‘no’.

dialogues.speaker: SHAWN
dialogues.text: When I was sixteen, Richie Conners called me over to his house. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: SHAWN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He knew I was pullin’ small jobs here and there and he asked me if I wanted to come work for him. Don’t make a decision now, he said. Go home. Sleep on it. Come back and see me in the morning. Here's what I want you to think about: There are two types of men in this world. The first man gets up in the morning and goes to work for someone. He works hard to make a decent living for his wife and his children. Everyone calls him a friend. When he dies, a funeral is given. The family gathers and stories are told about what a nice, simple, decent man he was. Then they go home and go on about their lives... The second man knows no boss. He lives recklessly and boldly, making enemies and hurting the ones he loves. When he dies he is blessed and cursed in equal measure. Parties are thrown to celebrate his life, others to rejoice in his death. His enemies toast that they’1ll never have to see him again. But those that love him wonder how they’1l ever live without him... I didn’t sleep that whole night. I knocked on his door at six the next morning. Pat looks at him curiously. Off Pat’s look, an explanatio SHAWN (CONT’D) Earlier, I was tryin’ to remember the moment when the boy went wrong. EXT. PLAZA TOWER APARTMENTS — NIGHT ESTABLISHING. A dilapidated, graffiti-plagued fifteen-sto housing authority building. Teenage riffraff outside. Smo dope, talking shit. Mange-ridden dogs amble. INT. PLAZA TOWER — 6TH FLOOR — NIGHT TIGHT ON MIKE pleading with a YOUNG MOTHER, 30, who cower behind a door chain.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Curtis. His name’s Curtis —

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG MOTHER
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, I don’t know anybody by that name —

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: His mom works as a nurse... probably Hahnemann, or Frankford Hospital —

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG MOTHER
dialogues.text: I’m really sorry. I have to go.  70. Mother shuts the door.

dialogues.speaker: A FEW DOORS DOWN
dialogues.text: Jimmy KNOCKS on another apartment.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Open up. We’re lookin’ for Legs.

dialogues.speaker: GRUFF MAN'S VOICE, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: Me, too. Preferably spread. INT. STAIRWELL — MOMENTS LATER Jimmy and Mike walking up another flight of stairs. Jimmy lags behind, exhausted, his breathing labored. Mike turns back. About to ask if he’s alright, but decide against it. Keeps moving. 7TH FLOOR — POV FROM THE END OF THE HALL Jimmy and Mike KNOCKING on apartment doors to no avail. REVERSE NOW — AN ELDERLY WOMAN Nervously watches the two from her slightly ajar door. Sh quietly shuts the door, TIPTOES into the kitchen, lifts t phone and dials 9-1-1... INT. POLICE PRECINCT — DALEY’S OFFICE — NIGHT Captain Daley paces. Can’t sit still. Night from hell and it’s still not over. He glances up to find HARDING and FL making their way across the squad room.

dialogues.speaker: DALEY
dialogues.text: (knows Harding, sotto) Oh shit... Harding and Flores enter his office. Harding has the disp log in hand.

dialogues.speaker: HARDING
dialogues.text: I'd like a minute of your time, Captain.

dialogues.speaker: DALEY
dialogues.text: What for?

dialogues.speaker: HARDING
dialogues.text: I wanna know why Officers Whalen and Edney failed to notify dispatch when Michael Conlon was apprehended.

dialogues.speaker: DALEY
dialogues.text: (incredulous and enraged) Jesus Christ. You’re really gonna come at me with this rulebook shit now, Harding!?  71.

dialogues.speaker: HARDING
dialogues.text: (reading the log) 9:36 PM — A neighbor sees the suspect Michael Colon, flee the house on foot. HARDING (CONT’D) DALEY (continuing) I got two officers whose Ten minutes later he’s bodies are still warm and handcuffed in a pileup on you’re already lookin’ to 676. I wanna know how the drag their names through the hell did he out there? mud? HARDING (CONT’D) Where were they taking him?

dialogues.speaker: DALEY
dialogues.text: Get the fuck outta my office!

dialogues.speaker: HARDING
dialogues.text: Who called in the favor? Was it Maguire? (no response) If you had something to do with this, Daley, I’m gonna drag you in frunna the Commissioner of Investigations myself.

dialogues.speaker: DALEY
dialogues.text: You'd like that, wouldn’t you?

dialogues.speaker: HARDING
dialogues.text: You bet your ass I would!

dialogues.speaker: DALEY
dialogues.text: Cause that’s your MO, right, Harding? Turnin’ over on cops. No wonder you've been stranded in Homicide for the last fifteen years. Even your own brethren can’t stand havin’ your ass around. That strikes a nerve in Harding. He starts like he’s abou have a go at Daley. Flores reins him in.

dialogues.speaker: FLORES
dialogues.text: Hey hey... easy... An OFFICER appears in the doorway. Feels the tension in t room and stumbles to talk.

dialogues.speaker: DALEY
dialogues.text: You just gonna stand there? What is it?!

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER
dialogues.text: Sorry, Captain. They uhh, they got a positive on Jimmy Conlon at the Plaza Tower. Harding shoots Daley a look: we’ll finish this later. He Flores go.  72. INT. PRICE’S AUDI A7, MOVING — NIGHT STREETLIGHTS GLIDE LIKE TRACERS across the windshield as Price cruises the city streets. The SCANNER CRACKLES.

dialogues.speaker: DISPATCHER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: All units respond to a Code 1. 2350 Tremont, Plaza Towers. Positive ID on the I-676 shooting suspects. Tac Air will assist, over. EXT. CITY STREET — SAME As the AUDI abruptly U-TURNS, cutting off opposing traffi Brakes SQUEAL. Horns SHOUTS. It DARTS OFF down the road.. INT. PLAZA TOWER, APARTMENT 718 — NIGHT THREE TEENAGE BOYS — ERIC, MARCUS and TERRELL (all 14) — away on XBox controllers, eviscerating a horde of posthum in a first-person shooter game. The DOORBELL RINGS. Eric, all baggy jeans and attitude, d his controller and opens the door on Mike and Jimmy.

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: (curt) Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Hey. Hi. Do you uh, do you know a kid named Curtis... or Legs...?

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: Who are you?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Doesn’t matter who we are. Do you know him or not?

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: How ‘bout you suck a fat one, old man.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: How ‘bout I slap your ass around, you little shithead.

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: You'd prolly like slappin’ my ass around. Eric tries to close the door. Mike blocks it with his arm

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Please... It’s really important that I find him. MARCUS nears.  73.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: Whaddayou wanna see Legs for?

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Do you know him?

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: He’s my brother. A look of relief comes over Mike. Then:

dialogues.speaker: TERRELL
dialogues.text: Check out this helicopter, yo! Terrell’s looking out the window. Mike and Jimmy move ins and SEE a POLICE HELICOPTER hovering overhead, SPOTLIGHT probing the tower. Below, a COVEY of Crown Vics arrive. C pour out and rush into the building. A look passes between Mike and Jimmy... EXT. PARKING LOT, ACROSS FROM PLAZA TOWER — NIGHT Price steps out of the Audi and appraises the scene acros the street. POLICE have surrounded the entrance. He appea to be puzzling through a code. Then: QUICK DETAIL SHOTS — AS PRICE OPENS the Audi trunk... PUTS ON a DRAGON SKIN BULLETPROOF VEST under his coat... slips a few extra CLIPS into his pockets... removes NIGHT VISION GOGGLES... Finished, he STALKS towards the Plaza Tower. A HORDE OF OFFICERS keep a rowdy group of rubberneckers at bay. Price bypasses the crowd, continues to the rear of the to Further down, he notices a YOUNG COP standing guard outsi second entrance. He nears.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG COP
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, sir, you can’t be back here.

dialogues.speaker: PRICE
dialogues.text: I live on the third floor. (points to a window) That’s my apartment there. I have to take my medication.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG COP
dialogues.text: That medication’s gonna hafta wait. Two dangerous fugitives are hiding inside the building right now.

dialogues.speaker: PRICE
dialogues.text: Oh dear.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG COP
dialogues.text: Yeah. Go around to the front —  74.

dialogues.speaker: PRICE
dialogues.text: Well maybe you could get it for me?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG COP
dialogues.text: No no —

dialogues.speaker: PRICE
dialogues.text: It’s apartment 317. (reaching into his jacket) Here’s my key. Instead of a key, Price removes a KA-BAR KNIFE from his jacket. IN A FLASH OF MOTION, he STABS YOUNG COP in the n covers his mouth, and drags his body inside the building. EXT. PLAZA TOWER — NIGHT Harding’s Charger arrives out front. Harding and Flores c out and join the crowd of Officers outside the building.

dialogues.speaker: VETERAN COP
dialogues.text: Hell’re you doin’ here, Harding?

dialogues.speaker: HARDING
dialogues.text: I been chasin’ Conlon for thirty years. You didn’t think I was gonna miss this, didja? Vet Cop smiles. Harding looks around, spots Sayers and Na nearby. Sayers smirks, waves. Harding turns away. INT. PLAZA TOWER — 6TH FLOOR — NIGHT BOOM! the stairwell door FLINGS OPEN as SIX OFFICERS burs out and march down the HALLWAY, POUNDING on doors — SHOUT at those inside to open up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: looking for Jimmy and Mike... BARKING at spooked and half asleep RESIDENTS to evacuate the building...

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE ONE APARTMENT BEDROOM
dialogues.text: COPS order a COUPLE out of bed, then flip the mattress, unknowingly KNOCKING OVER a candle on the night stand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As it IGNITES the rug... FLAMES LICK the mattress above.. INT. PLAZA TOWER — BASEMENT — NIGHT Price shines a MAGLITE on an ELECTRICAL PANEL. Locates th MAIN CIRCUIT BREAKER, SWITCHES it off.  75. INT. PLAZA TOWER — VARIOUS — AS THE BUILDING POWERS DOWN ..-HARDING AND FLORES look up as all the windows go dark. ..-EIGHT COPS in the ELEVATOR. It SHUDDERS, STOPS... ..-JIMMY AND MIKE as the ‘icicle’ lights around the apart go out. Mike tries a lamp switch... nothing... INT. STAIRWELL — SAME DARKNESS. Suddenly PRICE EMERGES FROM THE BLACK. Night vi goggles on as he moves deliberately up the stairs like so strange alien sent here with a single purpose. PRICE’S POV (NIGHT VISION): Seeing all in electric green. Light amplified. INT. APARTMENT 718 — NIGHT ON JIMMY and MIKE at the window, watching the helicopter circle, feeling the walls closing in around them. Mike turns back to Marcus —

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Where’s your brother?

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: I don’t know, man. Shit, my mom’s gonna kill me. COPS VOICES are heard just down the hall, evacuating more apartments. Getting closer.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Think. Where does he hang out? Does he have any friends —

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: The bowling alley.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Which one? Liberty?

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: (nods) In the arcade. There’s a game there he likes to play.

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: glances inside Jimmy’s coat and NOTICES the SW PISTOL tuc into his waist. His mind putting things together. A panic rises. He TAKES OFF into the —

dialogues.speaker: HALLWAY
dialogues.text: and CALLS OUT to TWO OFFICERS at the far end —  76.

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: Yo! Yo, them fools are in here! TWO OFFICERS turn, RUSH that way as —

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY AND MIKE
dialogues.text: having heard ERIC’S PLEA — RACE OUT OF THE APARTMENT — in the HALL — towards the STAIRWELL as the OFFICERS chase —

dialogues.speaker: FREEZE
dialogues.text: Jimmy and Mike ignore the command — The OFFICERS FIRE! Bullets narrowly missing Jimmy and Mik they burst into the —

dialogues.speaker: STAIRWELL
dialogues.text: and SPRINT UP the stairs —

dialogues.speaker: PRICE
dialogues.text: HEARS their footfalls two flights above. He BOUNDS up the stairs — glances to his left — SEES the TWO OFFICERS head for the stairwell — waits for them to enter his trap and BLAM! BLAM! TWO MUZZLE FLASHES IN THE DARK. Both Officers fall, shot in the head. Brutal. Efficient. Price continues up the stairs. EXT. PLAZA TOWER — NIGHT Harding and Flores among the cops and onlookers when —BOO — a WINDOW IN THE TOWER EXPLODES! Everyone DUCKS. Harding looks up. Black smoke billows from a 10th floor APARTMENT WINDOW where a fire rages. He RACES inside building. Flores follows. STAIRWELL — JIMMY AND MIKE As they reach the 15th floor landing. A door out to the r Chain-locked. Mike KICKS it. Jimmy joins in.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Sonofabitch! No luck. Then — VOICES SWELL BELOW. Frightened RESIDENTS spill into the stairwell. MEN, WOMEN and CHILDREN hurry downstairs. Some carrying Christmas gifts, others treasur possessions, one man hauls a flat-screen TV. Jimmy and Mike exchange a look, then quickly move to join exodus. Keeping their heads down as they descend.  77. Suddenly SMOKE CREEPS into the stairwell. HYSTERIA RISES the herd grows aggressive. Pushing, shoving. An ELDERLY W FALLS. Mike picks her up before she’s trampled.

dialogues.speaker: ELDERLY WOMAN
dialogues.text: (breathless) Oh thank you. Thank you... Jimmy glares at him: are you trying to get us noticed?

dialogues.speaker: PRICE
dialogues.text: moving up the stairwell. Pushing against the current. He SPOTS JIMMY and MIKE one flight above — RAISES his pistol and FIRES —

dialogues.speaker: BLAM
dialogues.text: RESIDENTS SCREAM! PANIC! EVERYONE HITTING THE GROUND as —

dialogues.speaker: MIKE AND JIMMY
dialogues.text: spill out of the stairwell — into the 7TH FLOOR hall as — ANOTHER FLOOR — FIND HARDING Amid the mayhem of RESIDENTS FLEEING APARTMENTS and the D SMOKE. Can’t see a foot in front of him. Grabbing every RESIDENT that brushes past, pulling him or her close to g view of their face. Ahab desperate to find his whale. 7TH FLOOR — MIKE AND JIMMY SO MUCH SMOKE NOW as they try apartment doors. Locked. Locked. Locked. Then — Jimmy turns a knob: Open.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Over here! The two slip inside the apartment just as —

dialogues.speaker: PRICE
dialogues.text: enters the hallway from the stairwell. PRICE’S POV (NIGHT VISION) The hallway empty. Filling with smoke. He starts to move FIRING AT DOOR HANDLES — KICKING OPEN APARTMENT DOORS — scanning the interior before moving on to the next.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jimmy’s scouring the space for escape routes. Can’t find

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Michael! ?  78.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: Out here! He follows the voice OUT TO THE BALCONY where Mike stands Wind carries smoke from the opposite side of the building

dialogues.speaker: MIKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (points) There. Through the smoke, Jimmy sees the ROOFTOP OF A WAREHOUSE twenty feet below.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: You're shittin’ me, right?

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: You got a better idea? Jimmy can’t think of one. The HELICOPTER circles, its SPOTLIGHT gliding across the of the building. Jimmy and Mike retreat, allow it to pass Mike climbs over the railing now. Looks down at the rooft gauging his direction.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Okay. One, two —

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Wait!

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Be careful.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ. Little late to start to bein’ a father, isn’t it? Mike steels his nerve, then JUMPS. The smoke obscures Jim view. He can’t see if Mike landed safely or not.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: (nervous ) Michael? MICHAEL! ?

dialogues.speaker: MIKE, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: Hurry up! Jimmy’s turn now. He dawdles for a moment before climbing over the railing as —

dialogues.speaker: PRICE
dialogues.text: KICKS OPEN the apartment door — SEES Jimmy on the balcony RAISES HIS PISTOLS and FIRES —  79. BLAM! BLAM! BLAM! SHATTERING THE SLIDING GLASS DOORS as —

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: JUMPS and — WE JUMP WITH HIM — THROUGH THE SMOKE — LANDIN HARD on the roof below and tumbling up to Mike. He clutch his ankle, grimaces. Mike lifts him to his feet as —

dialogues.speaker: PRICE
dialogues.text: Stalks out to the balcony. Observes Jimmy and Mike RUNNIN across the warehouse rooftop.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: feeling Price’s eyes on him, glances back at him through veil of eddying smoke.

dialogues.speaker: PRICE
dialogues.text: Returns the stare. Eyes on eyes. Killer versus killer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INT. HALLWAY — NIGHT — ON HARDING SO-MUCH SMOKE NOW and he covers his face with his shirt a his eyes are burning and he reaches the end of the hall a lifts open the window. Gulping in the fresh air when he notices TWO SILHOUETTES running across the rooftop below. He DARTS for the stairwell as — INT. WAREHOUSE — MIKE AND JIMMY Stumble across the abandoned warehouse floor. All naked p and hanging wires. Jimmy stumbles, FALLS.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: We gotta move!

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: I’m tryin’ goddamnit! Jimmy clambers to his feet. Mike spots a FREIGHT ELEVATOR They cross to it. Mike presses the ‘down’ button when —

dialogues.speaker: CONLON
dialogues.text: They turn to Harding across the floor. Weaver stance. Pis trained on them. HARDING (CONT’D)

dialogues.speaker: GET ON THE GROUND
dialogues.text: (Jimmy doesn’t move right away )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conceding, Jimmy sinks to his knees. Mike follows. Just as Harding starts toward them — GUNFIRE ERUPTS from the opposite side of the floor! IT’S SAYERS AND NANCE — FIRING at Jimmy and Mike — no interest in taking the two alive and — The ELEVATOR ARRIVES — DOORS OPEN — Jimmy and Mike LEAP INSIDE. Mike pulls the wooden gate closed. Harding CHARGES. Sayers and Nance, too. The elevator begi its descent just as the sides arrive.

dialogues.speaker: SAYERS
dialogues.text: Shit! STAIRWELL — HARDING BOUNDS down flight after flight. A man possessed. Flies o the stairwell — into the lobby and up to the ELEVATOR. DING! He levels his pistol as the doors open and... IT’S EMPTY. He looks around. Nothing. Just then, Sayers and Nance emerge from the opposite stairwell. Harding glares at them, indignant. EXT. WAREHOUSE — SIDE EXIT — JIMMY AND MIKE come stumbling out the stairwell into an alley. Jimmy's limping badly. Mike grabs his arm, helps him along. In th b.g., the Plaza Tower is a conflagration and — INT. OLDSMOBILE ACHIEVA, MOVING — ON MIKE driving away from the Plaza Tower. Fast. FIRE TRUCKS whiz past on their way to the scene, SIRENS blaring.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: (out of breath) Take Rowland... get away from all this shit... Mike hangs a right down Rowland. The sound of EMERGENCY SIRENS fading off, giving way to a rare quiet moment. Jimmy slips off his shoe, rolls down his sock. His ankle black, badly swollen.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: You alright?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Yeah...  81. Jimmy leans back and attempts to catch his breath. His be rising and falling slowly. So slowly. Forty years of two- packs-a-day smoking taking their toll. Mike glances over at him. Struck by how old he looks. Tur his attention back to the road now and — SMASH! IMPACT! THE DRIVER’S WINDOW EXPLODES as — EXT. ROWLAND AVENUE — SAME PRICE’S AUDI BROADSIDES the Oldsmobile — SENDING IT flyin onto the curb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON MIKE, stricken, addled, showered with glass. Looks ove Jimmy who frighteningly AIMS his pistol right at his head

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Geddown! Mike — snapping to — DUCKS. Jimmy FIRES at PRICE in the A cobwebbing the windshield —

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Drive! Mike DRILLS THE GAS — TURNS the wheel — FLIES up the RAMP a PARKING GARAGE — INT. AUDI A7, MOVING — NIGHT Price PURSUES. DARTS into the PARKING GARAGE. Vivaldi’s ‘Winter’ BLARING from the stereo like a battle anthem. INT. VACANT PARKING GARAGE — SAME As the Audi RAMS the Oldsmobile’s bumper — pulls up along it now. PRICE UNLOADS A CLIP into the side of the sedan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as the two cars RACE UP LEVEL AFTER LEVEL — BUMPING, SCRA and SMASHING into one another — the Oldsmobile FALLING AP piece by piece — bumper, side mirrors, hubcaps — INT. OLDSMOBILE ACHIEVA, MOVING — SAME Jimmy DUCKS as PRICE FIRES ANOTHER CLIP in his direction

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: (tired of this shit) Sonofa — fuckin’ — He leans out the window and FIRES BACK AT THE AUDI’S TIRE HITTING ONE — THWOOT! — shredding the rubber. The AUDI shimmies, then abruptly BRAKES...  82. INT. OLDSMOBILE ACHIEVA, MOVING — NIGHT Mike continues up the ramps, finally reaching the roof le He brakes. They wait with bated breath, listening. The on sound is the WIND WHISTLING at the windows.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Who the hell is this guy?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: ...Price.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: D’you know him?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: (shakes his head ‘no’) Just through stories.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: And...?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: And he’s a real mean motherfucker. Jimmy loads another magazine into his pistol.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Stay here.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Where’re you goin’?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: I’m gonna kill his ass. (off Mike's look) You got a better idea? And with that Jimmy steps out of the car. WE FOLLOW HIM as he walks down the ramp, unraveling the bandage on his burnt hand until it’s off. The ROAR OF AN ENGINE is heard below and the dull notes of Vivaldi and h lights a cigarette and the ENGINE is CLOSER and the Vival is LOUDER and Jimmy STOPS and faces the ramp just below w he stands. He TIGHTENS HIS GRIP — AIMS THE PISTOL as — WHOOSH! — the AUDI TEARS UP THE RAMP — A SILVER FLASH and Jimmy FIRES — BLAM! BLAM! BLAM! BLAM! BLAM! BLAM! BLAM! - he just keep FIRING as the AUDI makes its turn — coming r at him. He DIVES out of the way at the last possible mome The AUDI FLIES PAST — GOING SO FAST — TOO FAST — tries to turn — but FISHTAILS — TIRES SQUEALING —ERRRRR! SLAMMING into a CONCRETE COLUMN! It’s a hideous accident. The hood HISSES. Dark liquids LE The Audi reduced to a metallic scribble.  83. Jimmy gets to his feet and staggers close. Sees Price thr the shattered windows. Head pressed against the wheel. Glasses cracked. Face a bloody mess. But still breathing. Jimmy reaches in and grips him by his shirt.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Look at me, you sonofabitch. Price does. Smiles crookedly through blood-coated teeth. then LAUGHS. Jimmy PRESSES the pistol against his temple. Price LAUGHS HARDER, LOUDER, more maniacally and —

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: tired of the demons — so fucking tired of them — fingers trigger. All his pent-up rage surging forth. A moment awa from sending Price into permanent dark when —

dialogues.speaker: MIKE, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: Dad! Jimmy turns. It’s Mike, halfway down the ramp. Dad. That word. Paralyzes him. Jimmy looks at Mike... then back to Price... A long, anxious beat. Finally, he releases his grip, lowers his pistol and slow makes his way up the ramp toward Mike...

dialogues.speaker: DISSOLVE TO
dialogues.text: INT. LIBERTY BOWLING LANES — FRANKFORD — NIGHT Nearly closing time. Mostly empty lanes. CLERKS spray and away bowling shoes. And there in the arcade, backpack ove his shoulders, banging away on a machine, is CURTIS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: caught up in the action when he feels a presence. Turns t Mike and Jimmy at his side. He recognizes Mike and panics Tries to RUN. Jimmy grabs his backpack, reins him in.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: (writhing) Let go of me, yo! Let go! Help!

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Settle down.  84.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: I just wanna talk to you about what you saw.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: I didn’t see nuthin’!

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Bullshit. Mike glares at Jimmy: let me handle this.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: I’m not mad at you. I just wanna talk to you about what you saw. Curtis stops writhing.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: I aint no snitch. (beat, guilt getting the better of him now) I just... I got scared...

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: You saw what happened, didn’t you, Curtis? A long beat. Finally, Curtis NODS. INT. HOMIDCIDE DEPARTMENT — HARDING’S DESK — NIGHT Harding pours himself a cup of stale coffee from the old Coffee on his desk. Stirs in some sugar. Then a little mo as if recalling Jimmy's words. He rubs his tired eyes as listens to a rebroadcast of the 76ers game on a clock rad

dialogues.speaker: PLAY-BY-PLAY ANNOUNCER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The tip’s controlled by Brand and we're underway... Igoudala over the line... cross-court to Holiday now...

dialogues.speaker: HARDING
dialogues.text: Hundred bucks the Sixers don’t make the playoffs this year. He spins his chair to Flores who’s fallen asleep at his d Harding smiles, remembers being young once. The desk phone RINGS. He answers. HARDING (CONT’D) Harding. INT. LIBERTY BOWLING LANES — SAME Jimmy’s on the pay phone — INTERCUT JIMMY AND HARDING.  85.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Still awake?

dialogues.speaker: HARDING
dialogues.text: Yeah, I’m here.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Meet me at Frankford Center.

dialogues.speaker: HARDING
dialogues.text: What for?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: I told you my son didn’t have anything to do with this. Now I got the proof.

dialogues.speaker: HARDING
dialogues.text: Good for you. Turn yourselves in, tell your story, and hope someone believes you.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: We both know that’s not gonna happen. That’s what I’m callin you. You're the only one I can trust.

dialogues.speaker: HARDING
dialogues.text: So what’s in it for me?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: The truth.

dialogues.speaker: HARDING
dialogues.text: Oh fuck the truth. Do you really think that matters to anyone, Conlon? If it did you’d’a_ been locked up a long time ago. You’re gonna hafta do a helluva lot better than that. Jimmy doesn’t answer right away. Harding glances at the clock radio: 1:45 AM. HARDING (CONT’D) My shift’s over. I’m gonna hafta transfer you to one’a my colleagues. I’m sure you’ll find him very helpful. Harding hangs up, punches a transfer into his phone. Acro the squadroom, SAYERS answers.

dialogues.speaker: SAYERS
dialogues.text: Sayers. Hello...? Hello...? Harding’s PHONE RINGS again. He answers immediately:

dialogues.speaker: HARDING
dialogues.text: What else?  86. Jimmy stares at Mike and Curtis sitting at a booth... a realization sinking in... what he needs to do...

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Names. All of ‘em. Harding considers the offer. The words he’s been waiting thirty years to hear.

dialogues.speaker: HARDING
dialogues.text: I'll be there in fifteen minutes. INT. HOMIDCIDE — SAME Harding hangs up, then nudges Flores who shoots awake lik student who’s overslept for an exam.

dialogues.speaker: FLORES
dialogues.text: Yeah? What? I’m up. I’m up.

dialogues.speaker: HARDING
dialogues.text: (smiles ) Get your coat on. We’re gonna go meet someone. Flores sits up, clears his eyes, YAWNS. INT. THE ABBEY PUB — BACK OFFICE — NIGHT

dialogues.speaker: PICTURE FRAMES ON THE WALL
dialogues.text: -- Shawn and Rose’s wedding. Jimmy, a young man here, a drunken, merry groomsman. -- Shawn and Pat at a restaurant, arms over each others’ shoulders. -- Shawn and Colin at baseball game. Colin just a young b here. 9 years old. Back when he idolized his father.

dialogues.speaker: ON SHAWN
dialogues.text: sitting at the desk, gazing reflectively at the photos. H whole life on the walls before him. Pat KNOCKS on the door and steps inside.

dialogues.speaker: PAT
dialogues.text: Price missed... Shawn NODS. Perhaps he knew it already.

dialogues.speaker: PAT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Brendan and Robbie are headin’ down to the airport. See if maybe they can cut him off. Timmy and Drew —

dialogues.speaker: SHAWN
dialogues.text: Tell everyone to go home.  87.

dialogues.speaker: PAT
dialogues.text: (nonplussed) Home? But Shawn —

dialogues.speaker: SHAWN
dialogues.text: (calm but firm) Tell them to go home. A beat. Pat nods obediently, leaves. INT. CITY BUS, MOVING — NIGHT TIGHT ON JIMMY as the bus rattles down Cottman Avenue. He seems somewhere else. And he’s muttering to himself. Or rather to the demons inside him.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ... Goddamn you... God- fuckin’ damn you, Jimmy, you fuckin’... what a waste... what an awful fuckin’ waste you were... Mike, sitting beside Curtis, glances over at him.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Who you talkin’ to over there?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: (beat, then) I’m sorry, Michael.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: ..-For what part? Walkin’ out on me or not bein’ there for her?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: (considers, then) Not being there for her... Walkin’ out was the best thing I ever did for you. Mike reflects on that a moment, then leans his head back against the window. It’s been a long night... such a long night... all that adrenaline ebbing away now... he closes eyes... he could sleep forever... The BUS arrives at a stop. Riders stand and move to exit. bus rocks into motion again.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Mike...?

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Mmm...

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Your dad’s gone. Mike opens his eyes. Looks over. Jimmy’s seat is empty. H leaps up and moves to the back of the bus. SEES Jimmy wal away, down the sidewalk.  88.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: (calls to DRIVER) Stop the bus! Hey, stop the bus!

dialogues.speaker: BUS DRIVER
dialogues.text: Siddown, pal. Mike watches as Jimmy gets smaller and smaller... INT. THOMAS JEFFERSON HOSPITAL — NIGHT A quiet corridor. A few second shift NURSES milling about The elevator arrives and Jimmy steps off. Makes his way d the hall, peering into open patient rooms, looking for hi mother. All the while noticing the ‘get-well’ flowers and gifts surrounding the patients and feeling a bit guilty h come here empty-handed. He spots a poinsettia plant on the vacant check-in desk a quickly snatches it, tucking it under his arm as he conti down the hall. He scans the placards outside each room, stopping finally outside one: MARGARET CONLON. INT. HOSPITAL ROOM — NIGHT MARGARET CONLON, late 70s, thin, frail, is asleep on the Iv in her arm. Bruises on her face from the fall. The doo opens and Jimmy enters the room. Margaret stirs, squints to see him.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: Who’s there?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Hey, Ma. It’s me. It’s Jimmy.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: Jimmy? Oh. Oh. Well, what — what’re you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Whaddaya mean what am I doin’ here? I came here to see you. (re: the plant) Broughtcha something.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: Oh. It’s very pretty. Put it over there so I can see it. He sets the plant on the windowsill. An awkward beat. Jim uncomfortable. He’s never been very good at these things.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: How ya feelin’? You okay?

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: Well I fell down coming out of the Church this morning, yunno?  89.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Yeah. Eddie told me.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Eddie. (off Margaret’s blank stare) Your son, Ma.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: Oh. Will you put my glasses on? Jimmy takes her glasses from the table and slides them ba over her ears and sets them on her nose. A bandage above eye is peeling off. He fixes it.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Are ya warm enough?

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: I’m a little cold actually. Jimmy searches a closet. Empty. Moves to the door now and calls out to the hallway.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Hello? Anyone workin’? (KNOCKS HARD on the door to stir someone) I need a nurse in here. A NURSE, 40s, emerges from another patient’s room.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: Can I help you?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: My mother needs a blanket. Nurse removes a blanket from a closet and approaches.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, sir, but visiting hours are over.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: (accepting the blanket, then ferrying her out) Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: Sir, you can’t stay here —

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Merry Christmas.  90. He shuts the door on Nurse. Locks it. Crosses back to the now and spreads the blanket over his mother’s body.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: There ya go. That better?

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: Oh yes. Thank you. He pulls a chair close and sits down beside her. MARGARET (CONT’D) (shivers, pulls the blanket tight) I don’t know why they run the air so cold in here.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: You gotta be careful when you’re walkin’, Ma. ‘Specially this time a year with the snow and ice and... The Church — they oughta have someone throwin’ salt on the sidewalk for chrissakes. Them priests over there are so goddamn cheap.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: Did you get to see the circus?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: The circus?

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: The one that just came through. Oh, Jimmy, it was so much fun. There were elephants and giraffes and zebras. And your father came along with them. Jimmy realizes her dementia is taking over. But his time is short and he plays along.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Dad was here?

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: Mmm hmm. Riding on a horse of all things! Can you believe that?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: I didn’t know he could ride a horse.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: I didn’t either. Oh we had such a wonderful time. And afterward we all went downstairs to watch the fireworks. And your Aunt Joan was there. And Peggy Hastings... WIDE: Jimmy sitting beside his mother, listening to her imaginary stories, knowing he’s lost her...  gl. INT. FRANKFORD TRANSPORTATION CENTER — LOBBY — NIGHT Harding and Flores amble, scanning the faces of passersby clocking the entrance for any sign of Jimmy or Mike. Just then, Mike enters the lobby with Curtis. Harding nudges Flores. They proceed across the concourse toward Mike who sees them approaching.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Are you Detective Harding?

dialogues.speaker: HARDING
dialogues.text: Get your hands behind your back. Curtis watches as Harding handcuffs Mike. Harding and Flo have yet to notice him. HARDING (CONT’D) Where’s your father?

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Last I saw him he was heading down Cottman Avenue. Off Harding, disappointed but not at all surprised. EXT. FRANKFORD CENTER — LOT — HARDING AND FLORES escort Mike to the Dodge Charger. Curtis follows. Flores notices him now back, looks at him curiously.

dialogues.speaker: FLORES
dialogues.text: There a reason you're following us, kid?

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Yeah. I’m supposed to tell you what I saw. Confused, Harding turns to Mike.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: He’s my witness. EXT. PHILADELPHIA — VARIOUS — NIGHT As the CITY SHUTS DOWN FOR THE NIGHT... SUBWAY PLATFORMS empty... BARS turn off their lights... HOOKERS hang out i diner, telling stories, counting the night’s take. EXT. THE ALLEY PUB — BACK OFFICE — NIGHT Brendan stands outside, smoking a cigarette. Drops it to ground and twists it out with his boot tip. Raising his e HE FINDS JIMMY STANDING TWO FEET IN FRONT OF HIM.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brendan reacts, goes for his gun. Jimmy STEPS FORWARD and jams his pistol against his chest. Brendan freezes. Jimmy takes Brendan's pistol from his jacket, empties the clip tosses it down the alley.

dialogues.speaker: BRENDAN
dialogues.text: What’re... what’re you doin’ here, Jimmy?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: You know god damn well what I’m doin’ here... And if you don’t start walkin’ I’m gonna kill you, too. And then I’11l kill your whole goddamn family. You know I’11 do it, too. (Brendan nods, believes him) Don’t bother callin’ anyone either. It’ll be over before they get here. Brendan, bound by loyalty, doesn’t leave right away.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Get outta here! Brendan startles, then reluctantly JOGS off. INT. THE ALLEY PUB — NIGHT Empty. Eerily quiet. The door opens and Jimmy steps inside, pistol in hand. TIGHT ON: JIMMY’S EYES. Back in killer mode. Alert. Darti to even the slightest movement or sound. The Christmas lights BLINK. An ANIMATED SANTA on the bart clicks into motion, repeating a Ho-Ho-Ho refrain. Fear registers on his face. Uncertainty. How long has it been? Is he too fucking old? Then — AN ALMOST IMPERCEPTIBLE SOUND — A DOOR KNOB TURNING and — Jimmy CATCHES IT — WHIRLS to — PAT — across the room — stepping out of the back hall. He FIRES at Jimmy and makes a fatal mistake. He misses. Befo he has a second chance — BLAM! BLAM! JIMMY PUTS TWO BULLETS INTO HIS STOMACH.

dialogues.speaker: PAT FALLS ONTO A TABLE, THEN COLLAPSES TO THE FLOOR, DEAD
dialogues.text: (O.C.) A DOOR SLAMS SHUT — Jimmy looks up and — EXT. THE ALLEY PUB — BACK LOT — NIGHT As Shawn runs for his Cadillac, fumbling at his keys, dro them now.  93.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: exits the rear door now. He has a clear shot of Shawn’s b but won’t take it.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Turn around! Shawn pauses. Raises his arms.

dialogues.speaker: SHAWN
dialogues.text: I don’t have a gun. Shawn turns around slowly, faces his friend. The two men regard each other for a very long moment. SHAWN (CONT’D) Been a long night, hasn’t it?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Yeah...

dialogues.speaker: SHAWN
dialogues.text: I don’t blame you, Jimmy. I would've done the same thing if it was my son... Why don’t we go inside? Talk this through. TIGHT ON SHAWN’S HAND: as the HUNTING KNIFE falls from hi sleeve into his palm. He slowly walks toward Jimmy who lowers his gun. SHAWN (CONT’D) I wanna hear about Michael. (moving closer) God, it must be fifteen years since I saw the boy. Just as Shawn’s about to reach Jimmy, Jimmy RAISES HIS GU BLAM! THE PISTOL’S REPORT ECHOES FOR MILES. For a moment, Shawn doesn’t react. Slowly now, blood begi to seep through his shirt. A crimson blotch. He crumples the cold pavement. Jimmy nears, looks down at his friend whose breaths are s and shallow. He STEPS on Shawn’s hand. The knife falls fr his grip. Jimmy reaches down and tosses it into the darkn He tucks the pistol away now and sits beside Shawn and pu him into his arms and holds him like a child.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, Shawn... I did it for my son. I did it for Michael.  94. Shawn looks up at Jimmy. There’s no anger evident in his eyes. Only regret. Something the two men know well. Shawn tries to speak but the words don’t come. He reaches hand up and PATS Jimmy’s cheek. Forgiveness. The wind picks up. Jimmy takes off his flannel coat, lays it over Shawn’s bo As Shawn fights for his final breaths, Jimmy stills him, holds his hand.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s okay... it’s almost over now... Shawn’s eyes narrow... then slowly close... the light goe out of him and he crosses that line... Jimmy doesn’t get up right away. He stays there for a ver long while, holding his friend in his arms, keeping him w

dialogues.speaker: DISSOLVE TO
dialogues.text: INT. HOMICIDE — HALLWAY — ON HARDING staring at Mike through the window of an interview room. Flores approaches from down the hall.

dialogues.speaker: FLORES
dialogues.text: Patrol car found the limousine at a train yard in Germantown. Two bodies in the trunk. Kujovic and his bodyguard. Bullets match the gun found on Colin Maguire. Harding nods. Validation for what he already believed. FLORES (CONT’D) What’re you thinkin’ about?

dialogues.speaker: HARDING
dialogues.text: (staring at Mike) How some people get dealt shittier hands in life than others... Bring him a phone. Let him call his wife.

dialogues.speaker: FLORES
dialogues.text: You think the old man’1l turn up?

dialogues.speaker: HARDING
dialogues.text: Doesn’t matter anymore. Even if no court ever did, I convicted him a long time ago. WE FOLLOW HARDING as he walks down the hall. Stops at a w fountain, drinks, then dips his head into the stream in a effort to wake himself up. HARDING (CONT’D) I’m up, I’m up, I’m up.  95. He continues into the SITTING AREA where Curtis and his mother ANGELA, 40s, are waiting. Angela stands nervously, expecting the worst. HARDING (CONT’D) Hi. Detective Harding.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: Angela Banks.

dialogues.speaker: HARDING
dialogues.text: Appreciate you coming down so late.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: What exactly am I here for, Mr. Harding? Did Curtis do something?

dialogues.speaker: HARDING
dialogues.text: He did. He showed himself to be a very brave young man.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Didja hear that?

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: (relieved, then) Very brave and very grounded. MAN’S VOICE (0.C.) Harding. Harding turns to a DETECTIVE standing up at his desk.

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE
dialogues.text: Phone call for ya’.

dialogues.speaker: HARDING
dialogues.text: (to Detective) Gimme a sec.

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE
dialogues.text: Guy’s claimin’ to be Jimmy Conlon. Says he wants you to pick him up. INT. DODGE CHARGER, MOVING — NIGHT Jimmy sits in the back, handcuffed, watching the row home pass. The old neighborhood where he grew up. Harding driv Flores in the passenger seat.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: (finally) Can we go someplace else?

dialogues.speaker: HARDING
dialogues.text: (glances at Jimmy in the rearview) Someplace else?  96.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: I don’t want my son to be around for this. INT. STOCKTON’S DINER — NORTHEAST — NIGHT Flores is at the counter, sipping a cup of coffee. Harding and Jimmy sit in a booth, tucked back in the corn of the space. Harding sets out a digital recorder. Jimmy stares at the red record button. Almost laughs. Never saw this day coming. Reaching into his coat pocket, Harding slips out a sheet faded paper worn from age. He sets it on the table and sl it across to Jimmy. It’s a LIST OF NAMES. Nineteen of the be exact. Harding CLICKS a pen:

dialogues.speaker: HARDING
dialogues.text: I’m ready when you are. Jimmy lights a cigarette, settles in and glances at the f name on Harding’s list.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Ray Davies was a small-time hood used to pull jobs for Shawn. Bank deposit slots mostly. There was a score a’posed to go down in Newark...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: hear snatches of Jimmy's confessions to Harding. INTERCUT needed with the RECORDER DISPLAY TRACKING THE HOURS, JIMM

dialogues.speaker: LIGHTING AND CRUSHING OUT CIGARETTES, COFFEE MUGS REFILLE
dialogues.text: HARDING CROSSING NAMES OFF HIS LIST, etc..

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ..-It’s a strip mall now, but back then it was a nature preserve. Miles’a forest. That’s where I dumped his body. Couldn’t tell ya where, but you look hard enough back there...

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: .+.I remember he didn’t die right away. He just kinna... laid there for awhile, shaking on the ground like he was havin’ a seizure or somethin’. I didn’t have no bullets left. So I ran back to the car and got a tire iron outta the trunk.

dialogues.speaker: HARDING
dialogues.text: Then what?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: -..I finished him off.  97.

dialogues.speaker: HARDING
dialogues.text: With the tire iron?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Yeah...

dialogues.speaker: HARDING
dialogues.text: And who told you to murder him?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Shawn Maguire.

dialogues.speaker: HARDING
dialogues.text: What about Captain Daley? How long’s he been in bed with Shawn?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Thirty, thirty-five years. The night he graduated the academy we took him out and got him laid. This hideous lookin’ redhead Shawn found walkin’ the streets in Olney. Prolly the first and last time for that fat prick.

dialogues.speaker: HARDING
dialogues.text: He made the payroll in exchange for what?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Information. Names. Someone was gettin’ ready to talk to you or the Feds and he let us know. A FINAL DISSOLVE now. MORNING IS AT THE WINDOW. A bright rising to reclaim the sky. The ashtray brims with cigaret butts. Empty cups of coffee and sugar packets litter the tabletop.

dialogues.speaker: HARDING
dialogues.text: The Black Friday Murders. Ernest Hayes, Ted Grady, and Glenn Cavetto. Jimmy nods: them, too. HARDING (CONT’D) And those murders were ordered by Shawn Maguire as well, correct?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Yeah... Harding checks the final three names off his list.

dialogues.speaker: HARDING
dialogues.text: That all of ‘em?  98.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: (beat) Two more. Patrick Mullen and Shawn Maguire. Harding absorbs that a long moment.

dialogues.speaker: HARDING
dialogues.text: One last thing...

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Don’t ask me why. Don’t ask me that. Whatever reasons I had back then... they faded away a long time ago...

dialogues.speaker: HARDING
dialogues.text: I was gonna ask you to state your name. I forgot to record it when we started. He holds the recorder up to Jimmy.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: James Matthew Conlon.

dialogues.speaker: HARDING
dialogues.text: (into the recorder) Detective John Harding. December 22, 2011. 6:11 AM. Stockton’s Diner. Harding shuts off the recorder. Leans back. Stretches. Ey adjusting to the morning light.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: You have kids, Harding?

dialogues.speaker: HARDING
dialogues.text: Two boys.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Close with ‘em?

dialogues.speaker: HARDING
dialogues.text: I wish I was closer. But don’t all fathers? A moment.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Can I ask you a favor?

dialogues.speaker: HARDING
dialogues.text: (chuckles) You can ask.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: You got grandkids?  99. INT. DODGE CHARGER, MOVING — PA TURNPIKE — MORNING (DAWN) Jimmy sits, handcuffed, in the backseat, Mike beside him. Harding drives, Flores in the passenger seat. Jimmy stares out his window at the snowy forest of Pines. Beautiful this time of year. Harding glances at him in the rearview, then lowers Jimmy window, letting him breathe in the crisp, cold air. EXT. PENNSYLVANIA TURNPIKE — MORNING The Charger barrels past a road sign: POCONO EXITS 10 mil EXT. POCONO MOUNTAIN CABIN — MORNING A cabin perched high in a pine forest overlooking a modes lake. INT. CABIN — FAMILY ROOM — MORNING On the floor, Drew plays a board game with Catelyn and Li doing his best to keep them busy.

dialogues.speaker: KITCHEN
dialogues.text: Sara sits at the kitchen table. Warming her hands around mug of tea. Worried sick. Hasn’t slept all night. It’s a windy, cold morning outside and the wind buffets the home Windows rattle in their frames. (O.C.) TIRES over gravel. Sarah rushes to the window and observes the Dodge Charger entering the drive. Mike steps out of the car. Her body slackens with relief. She could almost cry.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: (composes herself, calls back into the den) Girls. Girls, come over here. EXT. CABIN, DRIVEWAY — MORNING Jimmy arrives at the front door. He turns back to Harding offers his hands. Harding grudgingly removes the handcuff

dialogues.speaker: HARDING
dialogues.text: You got twenty minutes, Conlon.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: (sincerely) Thank you. Harding and Flores move back to the car.  100. INT. CABIN — SAME Sarah opens the door and hugs Mike desperately. Pulling h tight. Not wanting to let go. The embrace is broken final Mike picks the girls up now and hugs them.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Oh I missed you guys.

dialogues.speaker: CATELYN
dialogues.text: I missed you, daddy. Sarah eyes Jimmy warily, like an uninvited guest.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Hi, Sarah. Sarah, hesitant, looks to Mike.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: It’s okay. He just wanted to meet the girls.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: (to Jimmy) This is my brother, Drew.

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: Nice to meet you. Jimmy nods, shakes his hand.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: (to the girls) That’s your Grandfather. Go over and say hi. Mike sets the girls down. They step toward Jimmy charily, coyly. Jimmy kneels down to their level.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: It's very nice to meet you, Catelyn.

dialogues.speaker: CATELYN
dialogues.text: Hi...

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: You're a very pretty girl, you know that?

dialogues.speaker: CATELYN
dialogues.text: My daddy said we didn’t have a grandfather.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Well you didn’t for a while, but you might have one now... Does that sound good?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mmm hmm.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: (to Lily) And you must be Lily. Lily hugs Mike’s leg.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Go ahead, sweetie. You can say hi. Lily buries her face in his jeans.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: You're being shy, arentcha? 101. It doesn't bother Jimmy one bit. Being this close to them That’s all he wanted.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (touching Sara’s belly) And this one here... this is Michael, Jr.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
