dialogues.text: (stands) Good name. Maybe you can teach him to play ball one day.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: We'll see. I don’t got much of an arm, but... Jimmy smiles. An awkward moment. The realization that years of hurt can be atoned for in a few moments.

dialogues.speaker: CATELYN
dialogues.text: Can we go see the ducks now, Mommy?

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: Yeah! Can we see the ducks, Mommy?

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: In a minute, girls.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: No no. Go ahead.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Why don’t you come out with us?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Yeah. Yeah, I’1l meetcha down there. I’m just gonna get some water. Thirsty.  102.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Okay. Come on, girls. Drew and the girls exit the cabin. Before Mike leaves, he turns back to Jimmy.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m glad you got to meet them.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Me, too. Mike goes. Jimmy is alone. Physically and emotionally drained. He mo to the sink and pours himself a glass of water. Drinks it a single gulp. Ahhhh... He runs his burnt hand under the water and watches the water move through his calloused fingers before finally shutting the faucet off. He paces around when he notices the COLLAGE Sarah was mak for the new baby on the kitchen table. ‘US BEFORE YOU’. I finished now. Every inch of canvas covered. He looks at it curiously a moment. Sits at the table now peers down at the pictures. So many. A mosaic of moments together to tell a family’s life. JIMMY’S POV The pictures. Catelyn’s birth, Lily’s first bath; birthda holidays, Halloween costumes, bike rides, etc... A lifeti of happy memories.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: His eyes well with tears. JIMMY’S POV VERY TIGHT ON the faces of Sarah. Catelyn. Lily. Mike.

dialogues.speaker: VERY TIGHT ON JIMMY
dialogues.text: It hits him all at once... everything he missed... everyt he wasn’t... And it just breaks him... it just fucking shatters him into a million pieces...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His stomach quakes.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Oh God. Oh God. Tears roll down his face. We stay on Jimmy for a very long while, fighting like hel hold it together... Until...  103. ...-something strange happens. Looking at the photos agai realizes... his son isn’t him... that his sins are his ow And a great relief washes over him. His whole body slackens as if a great weight has been lif He gathers himself and moves to the back door. Through a of glass, he watches his family down by the lake. Walking along the water’s edge. The girls pointing at the ducks.

dialogues.speaker: SIX BULLETS RIP INTO HIS CHEST
dialogues.text: He REELS BACK — tries to steady himself against the kitch table — but his legs give out and he COLLAPSES to the flo Through the shattered panel, WE SEE PRICE OUTSIDE. A haun visage. The left side of his face covered with crimson-ti bandages. His glasses are cracked and askew. Like a figur from a nightmare figure come horribly to life. AT THE LAKE’S EDGE Mike HEARS the dull echo of gunshots. He looks upward to cabin, but can’t see anything through the dense woods.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: (to Sarah) Take the girls.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Mike —

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Go! Now! Sarah grabs Catelyn and Lily and rushes off. Mike runs back toward the cabin.

dialogues.speaker: PRICE
dialogues.text: clicks another magazine into his FIVE-SEVEN PISTOL, then coolly starts down the wooded slope towards the lake to fulfill the second half of his charge. INT. CABIN — JIMMY clutching his bloody chest. He drags himself across the kitchen floor, leaving a streak of blood on the linoleum. Grunting through unbearable pain, he PICKS himself up, op the closet door and removes a KIMBER CLASSIC HUNTING RIFL  104. INT. DODGE CHARGER — DRIVEWAY — HARDING AND FLORES Flores notices Price walking through the woods, down towa the water.

dialogues.speaker: FLORES
dialogues.text: Who the hell is that? Harding lifts his eyes and observes Price making his desc He LEAPS OUT of the car and — INT. KITCHEN — JIMMY -308 WINCHESTER CARTRIDGES FALL TO THE FLOOR as Jimmy loa the Kimber rifle. He STAGGERS to the back door and KICKS OPEN. Steadies himself against the frame — tries to focus — but he’s dazed — fading — so much blood lost... He RAISES THE RIFLE — narrows an eye and —

dialogues.speaker: BLAM
dialogues.text: Kingfisher birds flee a tree. A CRIMSON ERUPTION FLASHES OFF PRICE'S SHOULDER.

dialogues.speaker: PRICE
dialogues.text: FALTERS, leans against a prodigious pine and calmly appra the gaping wound and exposed tendons and bone of his shoulder. Blood runs down his right arm which hangs limpl his side like a flaccid noodle. He can’t move it. Undaunted, he reaches over with his left hand and takes t pistol and trudges forward as —

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: begins to SCURRY UP THE STEEP SLOPE when he notices Price Just ten yards away. He FREEZES.

dialogues.speaker: PRICE
dialogues.text: raises his left arm, levels the pistol at Mike when —

dialogues.speaker: BLAM
dialogues.text: TWO BULLETS RIP THROUGH PRICE’S CHEST. He PITCHES FORWARD and TUMBLES HEADLONG down the rock-rib slope, coming to rest finally on a slab of rock, dead. Mike scans for the source. HARDING APPEARS AT THE CREST OF THE SLOPE, pistol still trained on Price... waiting for any movement...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Finally:  105.

dialogues.speaker: HARDING
dialogues.text: Everyone alright down there? Mike takes a moment to find his breath. Then it hits him. Jimmy. He RACES UP to check on his father —

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Dad! He SLIPS on the wet soil and slides all the way down to t bottom and gets to his feet, unfazed, and RUNS BACK UP ev more desperately than before, grabbing at shrubs, grabbin anything he can and —

dialogues.speaker: TIGHT ON JIMMY
dialogues.text: Very near death. Slumped against the frame of the back do The rifle on the ground beside him. His breaths get quiet and quieter until they’re barely audible. His life doesn’t flash before his eyes. There’s no tunnel or white light. He just dies. A gust of wind tousles the dead man’s hair. The wind HOWLS. The screams of the dead. FADE OUT. INT. MIKE’S ROW HOME — KITCHEN — MORNING Frost on the windows. Snow blankets the ground outside. Through the entryway, we see Mike come down the stairs. H plugs in the Christmas tree lights. Opens the front door lifts the morning newspaper. Bats the snow off and crosse into the kitchen now. He shivers from the cold, starts a pot of coffee. Moves to the kitchen table now. It’s littered with textbo — Business Law, Accounting, Finance — still open from his study session last night. He closes the texts, stacks them on the counter and takes seat at the table.  106. WE SLOWLY PUSH IN ON MIKE as he opens the newspaper, leaf through absently. Then... something captures his interest

dialogues.speaker: TIGHT ON THE NEWSPAPER, AN OBITUARY, (WE READ)
dialogues.text: James Matthew Conlon, Jr., 55, of Mayfair, December 22, 2 Vietnam War veteran. Beloved husband of the late Katherin Devoted father of Michael Patrick (Sarah). Dear brother t son of Margaret (Finley) and the late James Matthew Conlo grandfather of Catelyn Grace and Lily Rose.

dialogues.speaker: ON MIKE
dialogues.text: Hard to tell what he’s thinking. His face a melange of emotions: relief, anger, regret, sadness, absence.

dialogues.speaker: CATELYN, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: Daddy, can I watch cartoons? Mike looks up. Catelyn stands in the doorway with her ‘blankee’ in hand.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: (snaps from his pensiveness) Uhh, sure, sweetheart. He folds the newspaper and sets it aside. Catelyn sits at table. Mike stands, switches on the counter television an finds SpongeBob SquarePants.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Do you want some pancakes?

dialogues.speaker: CATELYN
dialogues.text: Mmm hmm. With chocolate chips. Sarah comes down the stairs now with Lily in her arms, he against her shoulder. She looks a little under the weathe

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: What’s the matter?

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Sore throat.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: (to Lily) You okay, honey?

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: (hoarse) It hurts when I talk.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: I gave her some Robitussin.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: Yuk!  107. Sarah smiles, sits down at the table.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: (to Catelyn) What’re you watching, sweetie?

dialogues.speaker: CATELYN
dialogues.text: SpongeBob. Mike takes out the pancake mix and a bowl. The coffee mak DINGS. He fills a mug and hands it to Sarah.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Thanks, hon. How'd the studying go last night?

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: (sighs) Long. Nine more credits. I’1l be glad when it’s all over.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Is daddy gonna pass all his tests? Lily nods. Mike stirs the pancake mix. Adds in some chocolate chips. Catelyn chuckles at something goofy on the television. Lily, not wanting to miss out, slips out of Sarah’s hold sits beside her sister, laughing when she laughs. Sarah sips her coffee and slides the newspaper close. Off the family doing what families do WE SLOWLY FADE OUT. THE END.
